three_macronutrients.name: Three Macronutrients
three_macronutrients.correct: The three main energy-providing nutrients (macronutrients) are carbohydrates, proteins, and lipids (fats and oils).

vitamins.error: Vitamins are micronutrients, not energy sources.
vitamins.fix: Vitamins help chemical reactions but don't provide energy. Macronutrients (carbs, proteins, fats) provide energy.
vitamins.action: Remember: macro = large amounts needed = energy. Micro = small amounts = helpers.

minerals.error: Minerals are micronutrients, not energy sources.
minerals.fix: Minerals like iron and calcium have structural/functional roles but aren't burned for energy.
minerals.action: Energy comes from breaking C-H bonds in organic molecules, not from minerals.

water.fix: Water is essential but has no chemical energy to release. Its heat of combustion is zero.
water.action: Check food labels: water is never listed with an energy value.

fibre.error: Humans cannot digest fibre for energy.
fibre.fix: Cellulose (fibre) has energy, but humans lack enzymes to break it down. It passes through undigested.
fibre.action: Cows can digest cellulose; humans cannot. Different digestive systems.

why_fats_highest.name: Why Fats Have Highest Energy
why_fats_highest.correct: Fats have the highest energy per gram because they contain more C-H bonds and less oxygen compared to carbohydrates.

larger molecules.error: Molecule size doesn't determine energy per gram.
larger molecules.fix: Energy per gram depends on bond types, not size. Fats have more C-H bonds relative to oxygen.
larger molecules.action: Compare CH‚ÇÑ to CO‚ÇÇ: both small, but CH‚ÇÑ has energy (C-H bonds), CO‚ÇÇ doesn't.

faster digestion.error: Digestion rate doesn't affect energy content.
faster digestion.fix: Energy content is about chemical bonds, not how quickly food is digested.
faster digestion.action: A food's energy is fixed by its molecular structure, not by metabolism speed.

higher density.error: Physical density and energy density are different.
higher density.fix: Energy density (kJ g‚Åª¬π) depends on chemical bonds. Oils are less physically dense than water but energy-dense.
higher density.action: Oil floats on water (low physical density) but has high energy density.

more nitrogen.error: Nitrogen is found in proteins, not fats.
more nitrogen.fix: Fats contain only C, H, O. Proteins contain N. Fats' high energy comes from C-H bonds.
more nitrogen.action: Fats = C, H, O only. The C-H bonds release energy when oxidised.

persistent.gap: You don't understand what makes a molecule energy-rich.
persistent.action: Compare structures: fats have long hydrocarbon chains (many C-H bonds), carbs have more O atoms.

lipid_definition.name: Lipids Include Fats and Oils
lipid_definition.correct: Lipids is the collective term for fats (solid at room temperature) and oils (liquid at room temperature).

only solid fats.error: Lipids include both fats AND oils.
only solid fats.fix: Fats are solid lipids (butter, lard). Oils are liquid lipids (olive oil, canola oil). Both are lipids.
only solid fats.action: Lipid = broad category. Fat = solid lipid. Oil = liquid lipid.

only plant oils.error: Lipids include both plant AND animal sources.
only plant oils.fix: Plant oils (olive, canola) and animal fats (butter, lard) are all lipids.
only plant oils.action: Both fish oil and coconut oil are lipids. Source doesn't matter.

different from triglycerides.error: Most dietary fats and oils ARE triglycerides.
different from triglycerides.fix: Triglycerides are the main type of lipid in food. Same thing, different names.
different from triglycerides.action: Food fats/oils = mostly triglycerides = three fatty acids + glycerol.

same as cholesterol.error: Cholesterol is one type of lipid, but fats/oils are different.
same as cholesterol.fix: Cholesterol is a steroid lipid. Dietary fats/oils are triglycerides. Different structures.
same as cholesterol.action: Lipid is the broad category. Fats/oils (triglycerides) and cholesterol are subtypes.

three_macronutrients.title: The Three Macronutrients
three_macronutrients.content: Macronutrients are nutrients needed in large amounts that provide the body with energy. The three macronutrients are carbohydrates, proteins, and lipids (fats and oils). Unlike micronutrients (vitamins and minerals), macronutrients can be metabolised to release energy measured in kJ g‚Åª¬π.
keyPoints: Fibre (cellulose) cannot be digested by humans

carbohydrate_energy_value.title: Carbohydrate Energy Value
carbohydrate_energy_value.content: Carbohydrates provide approximately 16 kJ g‚Åª¬π of energy. They are the body's preferred quick energy source because they can be rapidly broken down into glucose. Sugars and starches are digestible carbohydrates, while cellulose (fibre) cannot be metabolised by humans.
keyPoints: Lowest energy density of the three macronutrients

protein_energy_value.title: Protein Energy Value
protein_energy_value.content: Proteins provide approximately 17 kJ g‚Åª¬π of energy, slightly higher than carbohydrates. However, proteins are primarily used for growth, repair, and enzyme production rather than energy. The body only metabolises proteins for energy when carbohydrate and fat reserves are depleted.

lipid_energy_value.title: Lipid (Fat/Oil) Energy Value
lipid_energy_value.content: Lipids provide approximately 37 kJ g‚Åª¬π, more than double the energy of carbohydrates or proteins. This makes lipids the most energy-dense macronutrient. The body stores excess energy as fat because of this high energy density.

energy_units.title: Energy Units for Food
energy_units.content: Food energy is measured in kJ g‚Åª¬π (kilojoules per gram) rather than kJ mol‚Åª¬π because foods are complex mixtures of many different molecules. You cannot define 'one mole of bread' because bread contains thousands of different compounds. The gram is a convenient unit for practical nutrition.
keyPoints: Foods are mixtures, not pure substances
Cannot define moles of complex mixtures
Australia uses kJ, USA uses Calories

why_fats_highest.title: Why Fats Have the Highest Energy
why_fats_highest.content: Fats have the highest energy per gram because their molecules contain many C-H bonds and relatively few oxygen atoms. Carbohydrates are already partially oxidised (they contain oxygen in their structure), so less energy is released when they are fully oxidised. Fat molecules are essentially long hydrocarbon chains that release maximum energy upon oxidation.
keyPoints: Fats have more C-H bonds per gram
C-H bonds release energy when oxidised
Fat molecules are mostly hydrocarbon chains

lipid_definition.title: Lipids: Fats and Oils
lipid_definition.content: Lipid is the scientific term for the group of compounds that includes fats and oils. Fats are lipids that are solid at room temperature (like butter and lard), while oils are lipids that are liquid at room temperature (like olive oil and canola oil). Both provide 37 kJ g‚Åª¬π of energy.

calculating_food_energy.title: Calculating Food Energy Content
calculating_food_energy.content: To calculate total energy in a food: (1) determine the mass of each macronutrient, (2) multiply each mass by its energy value, (3) sum all the energy contributions. For a 100 g sample, percentages directly give masses in grams.
keyPoints: Step 1: Find mass of each nutrient (g)
Step 2: Multiply by energy value (kJ g‚Åª¬π)
Water and fibre contribute zero energy
